awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Empirical and theoretical approaches to understanding the evolution of gene regulatory networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. The project investigates the interactions between genes in the genome, which give rise to the physical traits of organisms. The specific “structures” of these interactions, that is, which genes interact to produce a trait, are often referred to as “gene regulatory networks” (GRNs). Variation in GRN structure is responsible for many differences in organismal traits, but how these structural changes to GRNs occur is not well understood. Understanding how changes to the genome alter the structure of GRNs and change traits is an important and challenging problem with broad applications. The project will tackle this problem by using sensitive techniques to investigate subtle variations of a GRN over different time scales and environments, under the mentorship of Dr. Patricia Wittkopp at the University of Michigan, and the co-mentorship a philosopher of science, Dr. Aaron Novick, to clarify practical ways to discuss and define GRNs. The Fellow will engage in teaching and outreach activities that will reach diverse audiences. 

The proposed work will use the genetic model system Saccharomyces cerevisiae (brewer’s yeast) to investigate GRN variation. This will be done by assessing the effects of introduced mutations on the expression levels of downstream targets of the focal GRN, specifically the TDH3 gene and its paralogs TDH1 and TDH2, using a highly sensitive high-throughput flow cytometry technique. The Fellow will examine the changes to GRN structure that have occurred within-species by quantifying the differing mutational effects on TDH3 and its paralogs. The project will also measure the effects of changing environment on the structure of these GRNs. Finally, the work will look at the focal GRN structure in a related species (S. paradoxus) to examine across-species GRN divergence. Dr. Novick’s co-sponsorship on this project adds an interdisciplinary element that will be incorporated into teaching objectives in both STEM and philosophy. The Fellow will also build a community space for early career caregivers in academia. The proposed fellowship represents an exceptional match for the career development goals of the Fellow who will receive training in a new model system, master cutting edge high-throughput data collection techniques, and receive mentoring in philosophy of science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The concept of gene regulatory networks (networks of genes that operate in a coordinated fashion to generate outputs) is important to our understanding of how genotype is connected to phenotype. The key goal of this project was to parallel theoretical and philosophical work and training with empirical work on the evolution of gene regulatory networks. This work helps us gain a clearer understanding of what gene regulatory networks look like as they evolve, and how we can describe the process of their evolution clearly and consistently.

The empirical work of this project involved three primary avenues of investigation. First, we developed a study system that can be used to investigate variation that exists in the gene regulatory networks within a species of yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae). We used a recently developed technique that can efficiently detect expression changes of target genes in response to knock-downs of the other genes in the genome. The first part of this effort involved building the instrumentation for the experiments and construction of requisite yeast lines. The instrumentation has been built and the strains needed for the experiments are in the final step of being constructed. The first experiments to be done will be describing the regulatory networks of key genes of interest in the lab, TDH1, TDH2, and TDH3, which are important metabolic genes in yeast. This approach will allow for these regulatory networks to be examined in various genotypes and conditions to detect subtle shifts in the networks of these genes within a species. Understanding the scope of within-species variation helps us have a better idea of how to model and predict what networks might look like as they shift within evolving populations.

The second set of experiments shares the same goal but is aimed to specifically detect differences in the cis-regulation (regulation of the gene’s expression by DNA directly adjacent to the gene) within genotypes of S. cerevisiae.  This was done by performing allele-specific expression analysis using a number of strains of S. cerevisiae. This analysis uses RNA sequencing of crosses between genotypes to pinpoint cis-regulatory differences. In addition to the insight gained about intra-specific cis-regulatory differences in this system, this experiment was also designed to complement the CiBER-seq experiment described above, as the data will also be used to select future genes of interest for those experiments. The requisite strains for this experiment were constructed and RNA samples were collected and sequenced. The data is currently being analyzed.

A third area of research was to complete work that had previously been conducted in the lab which spoke directly to relevant questions regarding gene regulatory network evolution. The work focused on how small numbers of mutations in known cis- and trans- regulators of the TDH3 gene not only affect the expression output of its promotor, but also affect the probability of some phenotypes over others being produced by subsequent mutations. This manuscript is now in final editing stages. Submission for review is expected within 4-6 weeks.

The philosophical manuscript associated with this project has been written and is expected to be submitted to journals for review in the next month after final edits. The paper covers the topic of how gene regulatory networks are defined, and why the definitions that are used can sometimes change, particularly in cases related to evolution of the network. The paper argues that shifts in definition are not themselves a concern, as long as the researcher has an appropriate understanding of the implications of the chosen definition. The work for this paper was also presented at the annual meeting of the Philosophy of Science Association in November of 2022.  

Outreach work for the duration of the award was focused on volunteering as a grant-writer for an organisation in Detroit called One Michigan for the Global Majority. This organization works to promote youth leadership and improve educational outcomes for young people in the immigrant community of Detroit.
